Award.AwardTitle: Kozai-Lidov Oscillations in Triple and Quadruple Systems of Stars and Their Compact Objects
Award.AbstractNarration:
Close stellar and compact object binaries are important to an extremely broad variety of astrophysical phenomena. Yet, most close binaries are not binaries. They are triple systems. Moreover, triple and quadruple systems are common on aggregate, representing roughly 10% and 3% of stellar systems on the sky, respectively. Most importantly, the long-term dynamics of multiple systems is not understood and fully characterized. Very recent advances in our understanding of the Kozai-Lidov resonance (and its extensions) have the chance to dramatically reconfigure our understanding of the production of close compact object and stellar binaries of all types. The investigators are at the forefront of these developments. They suggested that triple systems could produce "prompt" mergers of WD-WD binaries, perhaps leading to the Type Ia supernovae that are observed to immediately follow episodes of star formation. They also showed that mass loss in binaries could instigate the "Eccentric Kozai Mechanism," (EKM) producing close WD and NS-stellar binaries. Finally, and speculatively, they also suggested a triple or quadruple origin for Tycho B, an exceedingly rare low-metallicity A-star at the center of Tycho's supernova remnant that may be a blue straggler.
The investigators propose a broad suite of projects aimed at understanding the demographics, evolution, dynamics, and implications of triple and quadruple systems composed of stars and their compact objects. They will do both broad sweeps through parameter space, and focused studies of individual systems. Among the projects they will pursue, they will (1) map the space of the EKM and the Mass-Loss Induced EKM for the first time, (2) calculate the gravitational wave background and foregrounds from eccentric compact object binaries in triple systems, (3) explore the origin of the enigmatic ms-pulsar PSR J1903+0327, (4) attempt to understand the period commensurability observed in the recently discovered doubly-eclipsing quadruple A-star system
CzeV343, (5) develop evolutionary scenarios for Tycho B and explore the implications for other
Ia remnants, (6) expand the secular dynamics of 3-body systems to higher order, (7) compute the delay-time distribution of Ia supernovae formed from white dwarf-white dwarf mergers in coeval and dynamically formed triple systems, (8) attempt to understand the evolution of massive star triple systems with explosive mass loss and neutron star kicks, and (9) understand if direct compact object collisions can be driven by Kozai-Lidov oscillations.

A significant part of the work will be carried out by graduate and undergraduate students, providing extensive training in cutting-edge scientific research. Results from this research will be broadly disseminated by publication in peer-reviewed journals, conference proceedings, and by the press. In addition, the investigators propose an interesting education and outreach component that targets the public broadly, called "Ask An Astrophysicist!"

POR.DRECONTENT:
About 10% of all the stellar systems on the night sky are triple or higher-order (quadruple, quintuple, etc.), with the fraction of multiple-star systems increasing dramatically as the mass of the most massive star in the stellar system increases: more often than not, stars with a mass more than 10 times the mass of the Sun have more than one companion. Indeed, some of the most recognizable stellar systems on the sky, including two of the three stars that constitute the belt in the constellation Orion, are triple (Alnitak) or higher-order (Mintaka).

Triple and quadruple systems of stars and their compact object remnants -- white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes -- exhibit remarkable and intricate dynamics that remain not fully explored. The dynamics of these systems can fundamentally change their nature, by driving interactions, collisions, and rapid mergers. These effects have implications for our census of stars, for their evolution, and for the fate of their compact object remnants.

Over the course of this grant, we have worked to increase our understanding the demographics, evolution, dynamics, and implications of triple and quadruple systems. We have done so using a variety of numerical tools and semi-analytic methods. We have focused on assessing the potential importance of Lidov-Kozai oscillations, whereby, in a hierarchical triple system composed of a binary with a more distant companion, the inner binary is driven repeatedly to very high eccentricity.

Among the results from our work, we have explored the importance of rapid ``non-secular" eccentricity oscillations for the gravitational wave-driven mergers of compact objects in hierarchical triple systems, we conducted an analytic study that made clearer the characteristic timescale for so-called ``eccentric" Lidov-Kozai oscillations, we explored the dynamical formation and scattering of triple systems in producing new stellar systems that might then undergo Lidov-Kozai oscillations, and we produced the most detailed work to date to understand the dynamics of quadruple systems composed of two binaries, where the mutual Lidov-Kozai oscillations between the two systems lead to remarkable dynamics on long timescales. We find a much larger parameter space for high-eccentricities, mergers, and interactions in quadruple systems than in triple systems.

Our most recent work focuses on population synthesis of white dwarf-white dwarf mergers relevant for Type Ia supernovae and neutron star-neutron star mergers, of direct relevance to the LIGO/Virgo event GW170817. We show that in low-mass stellar triple systems, small white dwarf ``kicks” (from, e.g., asymmetric mass ejection) of order 1 km/s can change the eventual white dwarf binary merger rate substantially. Our work highlights the importance of dynamically disrupted triple star systems, and the role of tight binaries and eccentric mass transfer. The question of whether or not triple systems dominate the Type Ia supernova rate remains open.

We have also recently addressed the population of highly eccentric black hole black hole binary systems in the Milky Way. Given the observed binary black hole merger rate from LIGO, we contrast the expected number of systems radiating in the low-frequency 0.1 − 10 mHz gravitational wave band under two assumptions: (1) that all merging systems originate from near-circular orbits, as may be indicative of isolated binary evolution, and (2) that all merging systems originate at very high eccentricity, as predicted by models of dynamically-formed binary black holes and triple and quadruple systems undergoing Lidov-Kozai eccentricity oscillations. We show that the equilibrium number of systems expected at every frequency is higher in the eccentric case (2) than in the circular case (1) by a factor of 2 − 15. This follows from the fact that eccentric systems spend more time than circular systems radiating in the low-frequency GW bands. For a LISA-like sensitivity curve, we show that if eccentric systems contribute significantly to the observed merger rate, approximately 10 systems should be observed by LISA.
